posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497806
I recommend grouping values to make things less muddy. It could help to start with bigger shapes and two values first (your main light and shadow) then go into the smaller details and more nuanced values later. Another way to clean it up would be paying more attention to your edge control. To me it seems as if you went first with a small brush, which would explain the white spaces, but you don't seem to have a clear image of what the final product would look like.

I agree with the guy that a two stone study would be good but I don't know if I would agree with treating your current progress as an underpainting because the layers look very rough and thick to me the more you add the more uneven it will become. This was my mistake with my first oil painting 4 years ago. Instead of knowing how to take away from the paint and be decisive with my actions, I kept adding more over my mistakes up only to end up with my layers, texture, surface, and brushstrokes all fucked up so I had to use my thinner to wipe layers of wasted paint and repaint over after destroying all the preexisting paint. Thinking you can just correct your mistakes by painting over like with digital is a common mistake for people painting for the first time.

I also don't know if I would agree with the comment on warm tones, because temperature is more advanced than values. If you don't know your light and shadows adding more varied temperature will most likely make things even more confusing (mistake I do a lot the time). I recommend a zorn palette for temperature work, but I myself am terrible at temperature so I really can't give any advice beyond the basics and beginner stuff.

>>6498185
That’s not my drawing of Dem. I was just showing you what I meant by form. Notice how her face is depicted as a 3 dimensional shape. This is what your piece lacks.
Mimicking Alan’s style is actually really easy. If you want to get good at that you should collect shots from the show. Or use his artwork as a reference sheet. If yours looks off trace the reference to get proportions of the face then attempt to redraw it without tracing.
But you should definitely practice human anatomy by drawing poses from reference and studying the muscles.

>>6495776
Compositionally this is pretty based and the values are good at creating depth. Although, as a unity, the image looks good, when I break it down into individual parts it folds pretty badly. Like the other anon’s post >>6498217
you’d benefit from creating using a traditional medium. The tool you used to make the background and some other elements look like they were printed just looks fucked up where two segments of dots meet. Additionally, the little line tool you used in some areas like in the bottom right should either be drawn in or clipped in but the round brush for that intention doesn’t work. Another thing I noticed is that you should have drawn the sun instead of using the airbrush, especially since you didn’t use a fully opaque brush and I can see the dot layer behind the sun. Good work, altogether.

posts.name: Emco

>>6499643
Use brushes made for ink and let the materials work for you. Krink makes something called like the K40 or something which has an unusual applicator included with the ink. I recommend you play with some really high quality alcohol based inks and you’ll see what I mean about letting the medium work for you. Pens are honestly lame if you want to make loose artsy shit or anything that isn’t academically western. You can try water/charcoal base inks but I don’t have any experience with them but their properties are different than alcohol or xylene base inks.

>Have you had any income from your pieces?
Unfortunately no. Ive been trying to build a following but its been hard lol. I know drawing fanart is the way but I just like drawing personal stuff more.

>there's a level of mastery missing from your work
>the wolf sucks
Yeah, so I have really only been hardcore studying for about a year now, but started art in 2021 and have had an experienced artist guide me. We've mainly been working on anatomy and capturing likeness to reference, so it could be that I was just really feeling like doing more one day and decided to just jump into messing around with harsh light. NTA, but I would say you belong just along the edge of beg/int. Kind of in limbo between them.

You show decent enough anatomy in your work without breaking anything. The colors are decent, and the shading is nice. The boob is drawn nicely, though missing just a little more squish. The way the hands get sharp at their 3rd finger joint look wierd on the man, almost like theyre octopus fingers. I would have said you're comfortably int due to the mans grasping hand stylization, but as I look at it more I realize a few things. The truth is, the stylization disrupts certain things but what makes it obvious for me is the clothing. The clothing around them follows no perspective and is very all over the place from what should be just a standard look from above, aka birds eye view. The clothing flattens the image a lot due to its lack of following the depth of what should be the bed.

Again, on the anatomy front it looks nice, besides the hands. However the clothing and perspective definetily makes it far harder to place you int.

Blah blah beg this int that. Speaking normal human, its a nice drawing, just study up on perspective and for sure clothing a bit more to engrave that into your head when drawing, so oopsies like in that piece dont occur again, because once you see it you cant unsee it lol.

And those were not small design changes, it was changes like changing from one ponytail to 2 ponytails, then freeflow hair going on shoulders, then one just on the back. And the robot was changing from cube shaped to one shaped like sphere and then one that was flying, one that had limb and other one was just rolling ball. It was a mess, AI sucks at comics million times more then at hands

>>6506102
Well, you are right and wrong. Everything hits a ceiling, but with tech it is usually because people then have no idea how to improve it further. AI improves itself and will not stop at human level just because the training data runs out. There are already impossible algos that train AI on AI made stuff labeled by AI. This is how ChatGPT competitor was trained, one that is slightly better but not released to the public. We already experienced one singularity with AI in one field that is very simple for AI, Chess. Chessbots first trained against humans, then trained against chess robots and then hit skill ceiling in the stratosphere. First they beat world champion grandmasters, then they battle against each other and now we have chess bots that are something like several billion times better then the best grandmasters. CGI is still made by humans and you can only get certain amount of realism from 3D models that have effects that humans can think of. And the phone being a brick is because it was already perfect for the average consumer.

posts.com:
If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6505796
Yeah, it's readable. I'd suggest working on the symmetry a bit more. Try to make the snowflake mass shaped more like the wing, and if you can, try to make the snowflakes themselves more symmetric. Though snowflakes in nature aren't always perfectly symmetric, their flaws still follow the crystal structure - it's things like pieces snapping or melting off, or two snowflakes fusing together. You don't get snowflakes that are bent.

>>6506424
>>6506425
nice work. post the ref? are you going for a painterly alla prima vibe or autistic photo realism?

I think it partly just looks a little muddy from being overworked, like you started working zoomed in with a small sized brush too soon after getting most of a solid lay-in. there are some micro value shifts that could be cleaner, they look sorta scrubby in the close up (e.g. the shadow above his brow as the form of his head recedes). you also maybe started getting precious with small shapes and high contrast features too early imo. that starts to make it look a little uncanny, I think: notice the eye, especially. it looks strange next to his cheekbone-temple area, which is all flat midtone. the gradient on nasolabial fold where it touches the nose, and the little cleft on the tip of his nose, might be going too far at this stage, too.

try to suss out more medium sized shapes first after the big shapes, and then be very strategic about going in for details and not rendering until the last possible minute. try to find where you can maximize bang for your buck with just clean gradients and picking out hard edges first. your big shapes and value relationships are good already. I ran your painting through a noise filter (picrel), it removes some of the uncanniness and muddiness imo. I think that reveals that you have strong start and were just getting ahead of yourself.

I'm a retard btw so take all this with a grain of salt.

>>6503595

Picrel is the work she found, but I have long-since improved.

Backstory is that my parents are schizoboomers that don't know edginess is in vogue, and I decided to pick up a hobby during quarantine.

Sometime in my journey my mum found my pre-/beg/ sketchbook that contained picrel and I've been accused of possession; she apparently was so reviled by the contents of the book that she couldn't read through the whole thing. Mind you, nothing in the sketchbook was actually edgy-- no porn, nothing remotely suggestive, etc. Just rudimentary pre-/beg/ sketches/inkings of my OCs.

It's been way over a year since the incident, but what pisses me off the most is that she made passing comments about it for a while after and refused to tell me if she told anyone else in my family. She probably did because my folks got really uneasy any time I made an edgy joke or something for the longest time as if I was a murderer-in-the-making.

To this day, she still makes comments about it... so, it is what it is I guess...

Pardon the shitty articulation. I am too tired to write a good story rn.

well if you really are 'mindlessly' copying reference images then that'll certainly impede your growth. it can be tough to do for long stretches of time, but really trying to be 100% present helps a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6506446
gotcha. forgive me if you know all this, but just so we're on the same page:
not sure what resources you're using to study with but they should cover thinking about the figure in terms of it's component 3d 'forms', i.e. the ribcage, pelvis, head, two forms for each arm and leg, hands and feet. this is a 'constructive' approach to figure drawing that has you orient these 3d forms on the page in positions corresponding to what you see in the reference. it feels basically the same as posing an action man as you get better at drawing 3d objects (boxes, spheres, basic perspective).
so anyway, all that is a long way to set up that when I say 'an oval for the ribcage', try to visualise the ribcage in the figure you're drawing and mark that down as an oval on the page, and do something similar for all the forms in the figure. loomis and hampton and vilppu can all teach you what shapes you can use.

>>6506442
fair enough, whatever works for you.
but I'll say that I felt much the same way. the first couple of days drawing in silence were like scraping nails across a chalk board. but after not too long a clarity set in and I'm able to focus a lot better now. I'm not able to overthink in the silence because all of my attention is turned to the task of drawing (when all is going well).
so it went: 50% drawing, 50% yt/music, 0% bullshit thoughts
to: 50% drawing, 50% bullshit thoughts
to: 100% drawing, 0% bullshit thoughts
but the process of getting to that point takes time, is painful and I'm not always there, you have to stay vigilant and keep on yourself to focus on the drawing at hand. it's tough! but when you're 100% in that zone, like a surfer in the tube like in surfs up, nothing feels better.

don't know your particular circumstance, maybe you've got adhd or what have you, but I can say for me it was probably a simple case of frying my brain with constant stimulation. checking the phone first thing when you wake up etc..

Just a little context. When it comes to art I've been drawing for at least 10+ years now. I get commissions pretty frequently and have a small following but I've fallen to the trap of working only on my style and my fundamentals are trash, I rely way too much on reference even for the most basic of poses and it's even worst when I need to do backgrounds and objects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want to surround yourself with a large community albeit of beginners then Drawabox is fine but it wouldn't be my first choice. ArtWOD or the new NMA discord lessons Dynamic Sketching with Charles Hu would be. Granted I'm recommending these based on the fact you have some experience. If you're the type of person that sees better artwork by fellow students and gets discouraged then I wouldn't bother with these.
If you're ok with no feedback you have Sorie Kim's course on Class101 or even Foundation Groups lessons.

>>6490932
>or do you have any other alternatives?
Peter Han's course on Dynamic Sketching. Scott Robertson's How to Draw. These are the works DaB bases their exercises around.

Will doing DaB hurt? Probably not. But it's the dryest shit ever and lacks both the more free form life drawing approach of Han, as well as the almost architectural technical knowledge of Robertson. I did the course way back. It helped me get into constructive drawing. But seeing how you're already a veteran idk if it'll teach you much.

>>6494133
The brute forcing is not good. It will kill your enjoyment of art, and you'll forget why you starting drawing in the first place. I do think study is important, but you should apply your lessons to finished works (of achievable difficulty) while studying.
That said, you should be able to look past the superficial "middle aged men from the '50s" qualities of Loomis and see that the information is timeless and applies to any style of figurative art. Mangaka in Japan study Loomis. Don't be closed-minded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The most important drawing skill is unaided observational sketching. I mean that as your ability to simply draw from observation in one fell swoop - no measuring, no proportion guidelines, no autistic angle comparisons, no excessive abstractions to see the subject as a series of nonsense shapes, no adjusting until it looks right. Just drawing rapidly with a high degree of accuracy.

This doesn't mean when making a portrait you shouldn't use all of those techniques, or that when drawing a meant-to-be-finished piece you shouldn't nitpick it as much as you please. I just mean that in terms of overall improvement potential, the person who has the ability to quickly observe and effortlessly sketch will be able to complete more, and better, studies in a shorter period of time than those who have to really put forth great effort to draw from observation. It carries over to efforts to drae from imagination as well - the man who can copy Bridgman with 80% accuracy by way of quickly executed sketches will complete the study in a few days with fewer barriers between his observation and understanding, while the guy who has to carefully plan, observe, and measure in order to reach maybe 60% accuracy might take many weeks, if he ever finishes at all, and at some point the intent becomes lost as he resorts to brute-force copying, the images he's observing becoming the observational equivalent of hearing a word repeated too many times - images without meaning. The first guy is left with a clearer, better memory of the whole of what he copied and can therefore better carry it over to his own work, while the second guy is left with a pile of drawings that were ultimately an effort of labored copying as opposed to actual learning.

To be fair, focusing too much on what you like can indeed lead to lopsided development, because not all art involves direct carryover of skills, unless you try to learn some things relatively concurrently.
>draw what you like

>try to branch out

>backgrounds look like flat scribbles
>go back to cartoon comfort zone, with a lingering sense of regret or of being a fraud

>draw what you want
>draw countless meticulously measured and observed realistic figures and portraits
>try to draw something cartoony
>dogcomic.jpg
>prokofetus.jpg
>go back to academic draeing with a lingering sense of regret

Thanks to industrialization, urbanization, and the fertilizer. The population and prosperity of European cities exploded. Now the middle class could afford to buy art and they have different tastes than the historical patrons of arts. You also had other factors like photography and films replacing much of what these art had to to offer. Basically, the demand for traditional art dried up and the new generations wanted to do their own thing. It's very much like digital illustration vs traditional. Try asking any zoomer if they want to be the next bob ross or james gurney.

The reason has kind of been touched on a little bit in this thread. You can see the death of classical art play out in the late 1800’s between the academic artists and the pastoral “lower class” artists. Academic Artists lived in such a culturally conservative Christian world because that’s who their patrons were. So much of their genre work, what we recognize as mythological work, was trapped in the past echoing the same pre approved themes and stories from the Greek and biblical accounts. The work was stale. Take bouguereau for example. The absolute pinnacle of artistic ability but his work is mostly boring as fuck from an emotional or narrative view. The early impressionists we’re addressing that lack of meaning by making work that was real to them and had to do with the world they lived in. It was mostly great for a while but then motherfucking Picasso came along with his god damned cubism and then everyone stopped giving a fuck about the quality of the craftsmanship and wanted work that was more of the pure emotional state and less of the representation of what the emotion was derived from. The fauvists were high as shit. The late impressionists all had heavy metal poisoning from lead white and fake absinthe. The dadaists jumped the shark. The cult of personality period in the 60’s and 70’s was a blur of coke and ether. The naive artists tried to bring the art world back down to earth. Brutalists didn’t survive the 80’s. Album posters were the only real art in the 90’s. 2000’s were a joke. Now everyone is suddenly an illustrator/graffiti artist and acrylic flows like water. We are trying so hard to recover the identity that was lost. Thankfully ateliers are becoming way more popular but they still lack the ability to teach depth and emotion in art. The west doesn’t have a cultural identity or narrative that people resonate with, and we don’t even like each other that much right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6493566
This is classicism. Its roots are in the art and culture of ancient Greece, as passed on to the Romans and then to Christianized Europe. The art is not "realism," and was NOT displaced by photography. It is idealized. The figures are not individuals, but ideal "types" that follow proportional canons. Forms are simplified and monumentalized, and accidental or distracting details are omitted. Also, violent perspective, with its size distortion, is not a part of this art. Foreshortening does appear, but more so in the baroque offshoot. Classical art favors a depiction of the human figure in which the parts are seen in their true forms and relationships, and the posing of figures reflects that.
The subject matter was Greek myth, and later Biblical stories and historical events, all rendered in the classical style. Accuracy in historical costuming, accessories and architecture was valued. Educated people were familiar with the subject matter of classical art; it was a shared cultural heritage.
The historical changes that brought industrialization, communism and two world wars sounded the death knell of classicism. The old order was seen as standing in the way of "progress," and needing to be overturned. The audience for this kind of art mostly disappeared. Modern "classical realism" is not classical except perhaps in technique. It isn't idealized, nor does it portray classical subject matter.

>>6493566
These works of art were usually sponsored by the very rich for the most skilled artists.
Sometimes, the ones sponsoring had an agenda to tell as well.

I think the change began somewhere in the late 1800s early 1900s.

As demand fell and availability of art equipemnt rose, artists could afford to paint more than state or aristocratic sponsored works which was done, perhaos not to death but to some, somewhat exhausted.

That is not to say the traditional realist paintings WERENT done then, just beginning to not be the focus.

Furthermore, paintings of specific events depicted in famous realist paintings sometimes require great study which the artist may have to indulge themselves in, another skill of sorts which some artists may or may not have.

Artists also began to paint different subject matters besides what they were sponsored topics which you mentioned.

They began to paint the actual reality around them and the "fine art world" changed, they tryed different styles and ideas, questioning what art is etc.etc. but thats a whole other thing.

TLDR;
Demand dwindled as rich people typically dont sponsor these types of works nowadays.
Subject matter slowly changed around 1900 with artists being able to paint something else without always needing sponsorships as well.

As another comment pointed out, this question would already be answered in discussions in Art History.

>>6498614
I use a very tight 'precision' grip with my thumb,index and middle fingertips. I can only work on a single page or 2 a day maximum before it starts hurting.

The grip is so strong that when I put down the pencil there is a slight indentation on my fingertips from holding the pencil so hard. As expected, the paper gets pretty beat as a result.

I manage to mitigate this some by using a rubber grip or just putting a small piece of those kneaded rubber erasers around the area where I hold the pencil.

I honestly feel uncomfortable holding it in any other way.

I think good writing comes from other people seeing your work and criticism. So for DnD related stuff, you're basically subconsciously adjusting your character and the lore to fit the world it's in, and with your friend's character. Giving your own crit, and the more knowledge you have on both subject matters, you can make adjustments. And as you play, you can see how your character plays out with others, and from there learn how to take the character further on the next campaign. Kind of grows the writer here. And in turn, gives the character more Quality in the artwork.

>>6500787
I'd say focus less on the color, and learn to make a convincing solid drawing without it. Seems like you want to hurry up and get to the end result already, when really majority of your focus should be on the start of the drawing.
Let's say it takes 5 steps to complete a drawing. You want to make sure majority of your focus is on step 1 and 2, and the rest onto the others. Otherwise, there is some symbol drawing going on here. You'll need knowledge how How the body works, and not just relying on references.

So here's what I'd like you to do. Look for the book called "Morpho: Simplified Forms: Anatomy for Artists", it's a very easy book to find. Copy every drawing but Skip the heads. Only attempt to copy each drawing once. Judge it, if you feel the copy is off, learn from it, continue onto the next drawing.
Once you finish fully copying the book, do it again but from imagination. The imagination being; see the drawing, close the "book", try to draw what you recall. And go from there. Half your drawing time should be on completing this task, and the other half should be working on your personal stuff. You NEED to do both. As you do this, you'll start to make a connection between the importance of your studies and your own work. You'll be frustrated, you'll feel it's pointless, you'll even question why you're even doing this. This is normal, everyone goes through these emotions. Eventually, you'll start telling yourself "stupid fucking anon from fag making me do his exercise. So goddamn pointless I hate him. I HATE EVERYONE!!" but once you're done with the book, I guaranteed you, you will be at the level you were trying to aim for this entire time. And upon the 2nd copy, you'll truly ascend. You need the knowledge, without it you cannot get better.

>step one is research, the most important step, look for poses, drawings you like, textures, outfits, colors whatever, you might find things that already match your idea or come with new ideas that are cooler
>step 2 is the photobashing (if we decided to trace) you take 2-3 photos and mashup togherer (be it irl, drawings of other people, or ai genrerations now).
>step 3 is tracing, you have made your "reference sketch" on how you want the poses, composition, colors etc..., but when you trace you don't really do 1:1, just a loose sketch over it (you naturally need to know how to draw), then change the shit you want to change, sometimes you can do directly lineart without the sketch and use the photobash as one.
>step 4 color the rest, do the bg, finishing etc...

>but this takes more time that actually drawing!
Not really, in this way you set your direction since the start, don't have doubts or redo things midway, since you already know what the final result will be like, and if you are doing commissions you don't have the luxury of sketching and tewaking for 2 hours.
Starting directly from lineart sometimes, it's a big shortcut
>but if you knew how to actually draw you wouldn't need to do it!
probably, I don't consider myself a pro tho
>but it's copying!
yes it is, and if you don't really copy, you are taking "heavy inspiration" from other works, I don't advise it with personal works, but if you want to make something faster and precise is a good method (sometimes you lose 1 hour in research mode and realize that was useless, and just do the sketch yourself, you have to equilibrate things)

>>6476156
I've been a professional illustrator for 20 years now.
I used Photoshop for around 10 years for my work. Besides that I only tried other software for fun (Painter, PaintToolSAI, etc.).
When I started to work on some comics related projects I decided to try CSP (Still called Manga Studio at the time), because a few art friends said it had nice tools for drawing line-art.
It was love at first sight, because of it's pencils/inks brush engine and the feel of the brushes. CSP has the ability to use your stroke speed as a line thickness modifier and it allowes me to rotate my canvas (photoshop introduced that feature later on but it's crap to this day), which at the time was a game changer for me (check pic attached). Photoshop simply couldn't compete anymore for natural/traditional looking line-art.
At first I still used Photoshop for coloring and painting my line drawings, but then I completely moved away from it and fully switched to CSP.

CSP pros (vs Photoshop):
- much better line art brushes and engine
- canvas rotation (photoshop with his inertia thing is total crap)
- better color mixing brushes
- better perspective and ruler tools (out of the box at least)
- more stable (I haven't used Photoshop seriously in almost a decade, so this might have changed)
- cheaper

CSP cons (vs Photoshop):
- doesn't support modern multi core processors (when I switched to CSP back in the day, this wasn't an issue, since Photoshop was a resources consuming always crashing mess)
- more limited for custom brushes that involve painting

>>6476156
Long text well about my experiences with PS vs CSP
If you're new to digital art, I would still learn this first as this will force you to learn the brush system and all the basics. If you know Photoshop, you know everything. You can literally get hired at lots of places for just being able to show you can use Photoshop well.
People say that CSP runs faster but I don't think this is true. Unoptimized CSP runs faster, but if you just google "Photoshop 60 fps" "Making Photoshop Faster" from Borodante or KNKL you'll find that Photoshop can fully utilize multithreaded machine setups. Even with higher end PC builds, I've noticed Photoshop runs faster than CSP, even after tweaking settings for both. For some reason the cursor on Photoshop just tracks directly behind your pen much more accurately than CSP by a tiny margin, whereas CSP you have to do extensive fuckery to get that to be the close to the same.
For CSP The Pen pressure is more customizable meaning I have more options for line brushes and adjusting things. This is not as big of an advantage as you'd think though as for PS the Pen pressure control out of the box works great already, whereas in CSP you usually have to fuck around for a bit to get it feel right. Usually I end up changing all my pens to a straight or slight curve and make everything dependent on my tablet curve pressure anyway.
I still use CSP mainly for 2 reasons:
The program is constantly getting better and better, whereas the newer versions of Photoshop is actually getting worse than CS6 for painting artwork. With the future updates, it will surpass PS
CSP EX has a built in storyboarding feature that is extremely valuable for organizing and making a workflow for making manga/comics and an industry level animation timeline workflow. I've only ever dabbled in those, but I like the feeling that if I ever wanted to make personal projects CSP already has me covered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6501069
Latest version ironed out a lot of the critical bugs I experienced with it (no more random crashes). The preset brushes are very good and the brush engine is quite deep. It has some very cool features like applying filters in real time, which allows for cool stuff like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e0jrC1PDUYg
The blending tools are very good as well, it's very easy to get smooth transitions compared to photoshop's smudge tool. The downsides are some annoying over-designed features (tapping the hotkey of the tool you're using will toggle back to the previous tool used), as well as the eraser tool being very poorly implemented (it's not a tool in and of itself, it's a brush mode, so if you're using a low opacity brush and need to erase, the eraser will also be low opacity). Thankfully there's a way around this issue with tool presets. Expect to do a lot of googling how to set up krita when you start using it. Once you have it set up to your liking it's smooth sailing though. I much prefer painting in krita to photoshop, although I mostly use CSP now because its brush engine is phenomenal.

Krita easily beats photoshop for its perspective tools alone. One area where photoshop is still king though is stuff like the warp tool, liquify and other advanced image manipulation tools. Krita's aren't as advanced, and are way more CPU intensive.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

posts.com:
>>6505190
I don't think the foreshortening really works with this image. One, his leg is in a very, very uncomfortable position for it to be twisting out towards the viewer as it is. Two, from a compositional standpoint, we tend to follow the gaze from a character in a piece toward whatever they're looking at. As he's posed, the line of his gaze is broken by his knee. It makes the composition feel a bit cramped and less interesting than it could be.

Personally, I would do something like this. Repositioning the legs gives some room in the composition to build up a more engaging scene with the environment. But ymmv.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490726
>What did you use to learn colouring in black and white?


I grow up with traditional medium before switching to digital. The skills transfer nicely when you do shading on digital.
I also spent lot of time studying digital colouring/painting. From greyscale to color. That definitely help me a lot when it comes to determining value in drawing, though it's far from perfect.
Studying comic, traditional artists, or even black and white artwork is also a great way to learn.

>>6490823
>I'm curious what your routine for getting to this point was.
I'm the sort of guy that only draw when I find something interesting.
For routine, I keep in mind the mistake I made on previous work and try not to do it on my next work. The gap between finding new inspiration to draw my next work is the time I spend learning and practicing to fixed my mistakes.
I'm blessed enough with a good career so art is just a hobby for me to wind down. There's no use stressing about it, in my case.

>>6495210
>Got any inking/line art tips or tutorials?
I notice beginner tend to zoom too close on their canvas which result in shaking, uneven thickness in lineart. It's okay for detail, but for general shape of the drawing it's not a good practice. Try getting used to drawing without zooming too much.
Also practice on line confidence. Try not too rely too much on Ctrl+Z if you can! Sometimes erasing is better.
If you don't have any mood for drawing, watching speedpaint can sometimes inspire you to draw.

This is nothing to be ashamed of. You're actually trying to learn one of the hardest things on earth. Most people don't have one tenth of mental strength artists do and wouldn't be able to handle drawing for one week without wanting to blow their brains out or give up. Everyone is just coasting along taking the path of least resistance. And for most normalfags, that is already a decent path. We have to grind and practice and eat shit for years just to get the same dopamine normal people get when they scroll endlessly on youtube. You're a cut above, and you should be happy for that. It doesn't matter if you're 16 or 60, art takes the same amount of time to get good. Most people are worse than chris chan at drawing, but they aren't trying to draw so it rarely comes up. You, however, are constantly examining your weaknesses and striving to improve, so people notice your failures more, which makes you seem like a failure. You're not, you're better than people who don't try.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My tour through doing art has been rocky.
I went to an art school, but somehow managed to get all of the drawbacks and none of the benefits. Even now a decade later, my skills are not professional level and I'm still paying off the debt. I figure most would give up, I gave that a shot even, but I could never escape the craft. It was like trying to kill part of myself, I was a lesser man for the trouble. What keeps me going is a strong internal determination. I have no presence, no following and niche subject interests, but something inside of my heart won't let me quit. I can't, the very concept disgusts me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6494108
Go for it man. I've studied with people who became successful artists starting at the age of 40 or 50, all the cynicism here is a meme. The field is hard but if you work at it and really think about the work you're doing and who it's for you can definitely find a niche.

The best advice I can give you is to try and find classes or studios by you. Just walk-ins for figure drawing, not an art school or anything like that. Self study can definitely work for some people but you'll always improve more efficiently if you're with a community and have people giving you live advice. Watching How to Draw streams and pirating art books is the fastest way to stagnate if you don't know exactly what you're doing.

Oh, i just paint where i sleep, and then I open the windows to ventilate the room, and put the painting on the balcony to dry.

>>6489241
Yes, it is certainly possible that Kentaro Miura created the character of Guts in Berserk as a form of wish fulfillment. Many artists draw inspiration from their own desires, dreams, and experiences when creating their works. They often use their art as a means of exploring and expressing these desires in a creative and imaginative way.

It's not uncommon for writers, painters, and other creatives to use their art as a way to escape the realities of their lives, and to bring their deepest desires and fantasies to life. This allows them to live vicariously through their characters and to experience things they may not otherwise have the opportunity to experience.

In the case of Berserk, it's likely that Miura was inspired by his own desires and dreams when he created the world and characters of the manga. Guts, with his muscular physique, towering height, and powerful weapons, may represent the idealized self that Miura aspired to become. Similarly, the character of Casca, with her tomboyish attitude and attractive appearance, may represent the kind of partner that Miura wanted by his side.

Whether he was conscious of this or not, the result is a visually rich and highly engaging manga that has captured the hearts and imaginations of millions of readers around the world

It's likely that Kentaro Miura was inspired by the themes and stories of mythology and ancient epics when he wrote the Lost Children Arc and the Eclipse in Berserk. Many myths and epics throughout history feature tales of evil, violence, and tragedy, and Miura may have drawn on these stories as a source of inspiration.

For example, the epic of Gilgamesh features themes of power, mortality, and tragedy, and it is possible that Miura was influenced by these themes when he wrote the Eclipse. Similarly, many myths and legends feature stories of gods and heroes battling against evil forces, and this theme is evident in the Lost Children Arc of Berserk.

posts.com:
Why you should not trust youtube shills:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twy5Wo8m284

If you have any additional questions, ask them.
Remember to ignore all chinese shills.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

Previous: >>6472466

>>6494233
I have an Artisul D16 (not pro) that I bought for about 300 of my local pesos a few years ago that I only just started using properly a few months ago when I started learning digital painting very seriously. It's a 15.6 inch screen drawing tablet.
I have been very fortunate that it doesn't seem to have any hardware issues (some scary reviews out there lmao) so far, but holy sweet mother does its software suck.
Coming from an ancient wacoom bamboo from like 2012 I just cannot believe how bad the software is. In general I am extremely grateful that the tablet was so cheap because I was that guy who thought that a screen less one would be just as good but let me tell you now that I've seen the light I can never go back.
The problem is that the D16's drivers are being held together with duct tape and cum and it just barely works even having lots of strange issues like I can't use the two side buttons on the pen because pressing one even for a second will remap the stylus to half way between my main monitor and the d16 display which I sometimes can't even fix upon several restarts of the computer. Loads of little headaches and setting it up for left handed use was hell.

Basically I never want another Chinese tablet again. I'm still running windows 10 and the driver to this tablet hasn't been updated since 2018 so I am mentally preparing myself for this tablet to just stop working when I'm forced to upgrade to win11 probly within the next year.
I dont use pen tilt and I've found that 15.6 inches I about all the space I have on my tiny desk and so far I haven't found that I wished the tablet was bigger (only that it worked better).
I have no idea about any of this tech stuff but all I want is a functional tablet with good software and support. I dont use pen tilt or even need buttons on the tablet (I have a keyboard). Because if this I'm heavily leaning to a less feature packed Wacom. I really don't want to buy used. Any ideas?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I actually got curious about the origins of pen tablets and I found many interesting things.

Of course, Wacom is Wacom, founded in Japan and still the top in quality.

Huion is an independent company from Shenzhen China, which you might notice, a lot of drawing tablets come from Shenzhen, this is not surprising as the place is actually known for tech export.
Anyway, it doesn't seem to be owned by some parent company or belong to a group, which is actually rare for China to be owned still as closely as a private company as it can with a single definitive CEO.

You have then the Havon Ugee group, also from Shenzhen.
They own: XP-Pen, Xencelabs and Ugee, which doesn't mean they're the same, I'm sure they have different R&D groups (I'd like to believe Ugee has one), but it means they can cooperate if mandated by the group, probably to share some info or tech or something.
You would think Ugee is their main selling company but no, it's XP-PEN, probably because unlike the other two XP-PEN is actually a Japanese-Taiwanese company that got bought, so it had a better start in the race and I'm sure is doing the heavy lifting on the group, both as r&d and in sales.
This sharing of tech would also explain Ugee's unconventional good quality, for a price range so cheap you would expect them to break apart in contact, but that's headcanon.
Xencelabs is their "premium brand", they appeared as a "Wacom killer" with some neat toys and elegant designs, but I don't know anyone who actually uses a Xencelabs over an XP-Pen, because even if they were better quality than an XP-PEN, and I doubt they reach newer Huion's, they do reach those Wacom prices.

Gaomon is from Guangzhou
Parblo is from Shenzhen
Veikk from Beijing
Not a lot of info on them, but neither seems to be owned by a group.

The statement that "pornography is the highest form of pure visual art" is incorrect and oversimplifies the role and purpose of art. Art is a form of human expression that has the power to evoke a wide range of emotions, spark creativity, and provide insight into the human experience.

Art also has the ability to uplift, inspire, and foster empathy. Through art, we can explore the beauty of life, the complexities of the human condition, and the majesty of the natural world. Art has the power to bring people together and create a sense of shared experience and understanding.

In contrast, pornography is often created for the sole purpose of sexual gratification and is focused on objectifying and exploiting people. It can damage the soul and harm society by promoting unhealthy attitudes and behaviors towards sex and relationships.

Art has the power to do so much more than just evoke a single emotion, it has the ability to challenge, educate, and transform the world. Therefore, to say that pornography is the highest form of pure visual art is a narrow and misguided perspective that fails to fully appreciate the depth and breadth of what art can accomplish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:
https://youtu.be/YVAtRojlCS8
https://youtu.be/cF2UtfFT7y8

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

>>6504329
>I want to get better at painting. My skill in line art and painting arent equal and its time to fix it.
if your goal/assignment isn't to use a particular construction method for now, and you can just copy what you see, then I recommend mentally detaching it from your drawing habits. think more about shapes and edges instead of lines, especially during your block in phase; the whole picture as irregular, interlocking, straight-edged shapes. think about it in terms of light and shadow if the source allows. block ins are the most important thing to get right. mark tennant is an awesome painter who basically just does block ins.

I can give more info or critique if you want, but here's are some lines I drew over your (modified) ref to illustrate. the yellow is an envelope with too many edges, and the green is to sort of highlight what I would casually consider to be barriers between light and shadow.

dorian iten has some really good videos about it that I recommend. I find that over time, his advice is what sticks for me and has helped me the most. his advice helped me a lot with accuracy, identifying value relationships, and thinking about process.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZ0lz7W0CYs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483868
india ink can be a lot of different products. some have no binder, some have gelatin glue as binder with the lamp black in colloidal suspension, some have shellac as binder in a weak alkaline solution, and maybe some even are based on whatever dye. the ones pigments can stay without binder because the particles are very small or also because the particles have some tarry residue. they are usually waterproof or claim to when dry but often not completely. i don't see why in the case of gelatin or shellac binder since gelatin dissolves with enough moisture and warmth, while alkaline salts remain after the water evaporates.
acrylic ink is more waterproof when dry. it can dissolve with alcohol.
you might see more differences if you use them with other media.

It technically rotates, but i did not really notice any impact on keeping my lead sharp. Im used to my own control over thigns like that. Dont recommend, but your milage may vary. Pentel Graphgear 1000 is nice, but doesnt have the same heft as the Staedtler. I only have 1 of those. If serious about it or do drafting, Id recommend getting rotring 600. its full metal body and pretty much the best possible mechanical pencil you can possibly buy. everything about it is fantastic. the feel, weight, how much lead comes out with each click, durability, etc. the others have mostly plastic construction with a metal tip. this thing will last you forever and can pass on to your kids type of deal. if you need perfection, that is the one to get. super expensive for a pencil though.

for sizes, it comes down to what you draw and the size of the paper/lines you want. 0.5mm is a good starting point. i dont think you will want the 0.7 or 0.9 options. fairly large lead size. if going that big, youre better off looking into lead holders. a 2mm is nice for just roughing in lines and i let my go dull so its not making hard lines/easier to erase. once youve got your gesture/shapes in, you can switch to a 0.5 or smaller for details depending on the actual drawing space/size of the page. 0.3 is my detail size usually. i dont go smaller often unless its some architecture/drafting thing im doing where there are more standards for lines. like id do a person/anime/comic book character in 0.5 and the eyes or any smaller details with 0.3. could do the whole thing in either size though. i dont think you need a million pencils. i just happen to have them for various work and commercial reasons.

for lead, i have a lot. 2B or HB is all youll probably need. ive got pencils of multiple sizes with 8H, 4H, 2H, 2B, HB, etc.

posts.com:
>>6500480
depends if you are practicing right or just mindlessly get it done mentality etc. if you dont actively do anythign to improve and just repeat osme exercise you arent really sure why you are doing, you obviously wont improve even after hundreds of hours. if you slow down and analyze your practice exercises and actively look for mistakes and correct them, then you should improve.

for example, if you are doing ellipses or line weight or feathering/crosshatching and just scribble lines, thats not accomplishing anything. you are finishing the exercise, but its the same mistakes as the day before. you just wasted 15 minutes doing it or whatever.

when im in portrait mode, i'll do loomis heads from free references and full construction, etc. takes about half hour to do a head or two, depending on angle/difficulty/if i render it at all. the point is i am focusing on measurements, anatomy and actively measuring and trying to improve my portraits and construction. i'm not just filling a page with doodle heads and calling it practice. sometimes ill do the literal loomis plates.

practice makes perfect, but practicing wrong will always be wrong.

The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.

>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )

How are your profits? Do advertise your work outside of this place?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497881
Hi anon. I mainly make profits from selling my books and original page art at art shows and comic and anime conventions. I fund my print runs with crowdfunding campaigns, and then sell the books for pure profit at shows. My evergreen bestseller is Purrvana, a colorful watercolor painted psychedelic cat graphic novel that appeals to normies of all ages and all demographics from bikers to gangsters to grannies to crazy cat ladies. I have sold over 2,500 copies of Purrvana to date. I also make money from commissions, both my OCs and other people. Most of my commissions are catfight wrestling matches featuring my OCs or other people's OCs. I advertise mainly on pixiv, discord, twitter and my webcomic also works as an advertisement. I also drew animal coloring books years ago that still sell, at shows and online. After a bad experience working with a publisher several years ago, I began self publishing and now that's all I want to do.

I read that Image creators are in the red and go in to debt with Image unless their book sells a certain amount of copies. I recently read tweets from an image artist who says that after his book he worked on sold 5 issues at 15,000 issues each, he only made $1100 in profit and he got paid months after the final issue came out, after the profit share was split with image, the writer and colorist. I don't sell a high volume of copies, and my crowdfunders don't go crazy, but I still make a lot more profit than that Image artist whose book was selling 15,000 copies each issue for example because I keep all the profit of sales for myself. I also do freelance work. Advertising and marketing is not really something I'm good at, but I'm getting by and trying to improve at it. I'm also going to start a life drawing class at my local Junior College next week and I hope it will up my skills so I can charge more for commissions, and it will also improve my comic pages. No rest for the wicked.

>But now Im starting feel the idea is over done and Im wondering if I should revise it.
As long you have a unique 'twitst' or take on the genre then you'll still stand out in an oversaturated market.
I'd even go as far as say it can be advantageous to use a popular genre/setting like isekai because your audience will immediatly know what to expect.
>"It's an isekai with cool battles, knights, monsters and magic? It's just like the other isekai's I love!"
You can essentially bait an audience and have fun with it by subverting isekai tropes and expectations.
>"that isekai by anon isn't like your average isekai! It looks generic at the beginning but slowly turns into this super deep subversion of the genre. It's fucking peak fiction!"

That's for example the kind of comments isekais like Mushoku Tensei, Re:Zero, Tanya the evil and Konosuba get.
>"It's an isekai but without the shitty writing and blatant power fantasy elements. I swear it's good!"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write up a rough outline, then do dialogue, then do another pass and at least one rewrite before I start on chapter 2, then I keep going until the entire thing is written and I don't have a single page drawn because I'm eternally ngmi
Then I start it all over again with a new idea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write the dialogue right onto the page, using it as a sort of marker for where the panel's going to be (also using a brief non-dialogue description of the panel if there's no dialogue I think I might forget what's supposed to go there) for a few pages at a time, then I go back and quickly storyboard it. I do this in chunks of 2-5 pages at a time, not really coinciding with scenes or anything. This allows me to work out the pacing, phrasing and dialogue all at once.

>i mean when you couldn't download it and you knew that
I felt stupid after I spent so much time putting together that imagine and re-read your request. You can get a script to do it with Tampermonkey, too; the disadvantage of these methods is that you're still up against a limit of how many pictures you're allowed to access in a given period of time. This limit regenerates pretty quickly, but not *that* fast. Like I said in >>6462087, there are books and collections on there worth many thousands of Gallery Points, and you'd hit your limit pretty quickly downloading those via script - anyone would.

On the plus side, it still doesn't cost any money to use a script ... so there is that.

as somone who just started learning the figure using both proko and vilppu simultaneously, it's astounding how different proko's approach to gesture is than vilppus.

Proko constantly says "MOTION NOT CONTOUR" but all his demo videos are him simplifying contours.... then you look at vilppu and you see him making these fluid lines that actually seem related to motion and realize how stiff proko's shit is

desu tho, proko's gesture is much easier for a beg to learn. I still really struggle to do gesture in the same manner as vilppu and this is my third week grinding it.

>>6490009
>Are the mega links still dead?
Most of the old ones will be, since MEGA would have forcibly removed the content when it was reported. Even if one of us were to re-upload the same file, the link would be different. As a precaution, now, we're encoding the links (see >>6465260) ... except for E-Hentai, which - let's face it - is not going to pull down anything unless it violates their own twisted internal standards (see https://ehwiki.org/wiki/Expunging#Forbidden).

There are still a few gems out there, though, and some of the old books have come back with new links because they're in different places.

posts.com:
I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

I also post comics but those don't do very well in terms of numbers despite getting lots of positive comments and stuff.

How did you guys break through the limit? Is the solution really just to keep drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

>>6434940
I'm stuck at 230 or so but I only do original stuff mostly. Try doing fanart or drawing bigger account OCs. The only reason I am at 230 and not 30 is because I did art for someone's OC I like and they RT'd it. But do it only if you like their art otherwise it's scummy imo.

Also meme shit does very well, if you can take an existing meme and put a creative spin on it or make it relatable artist shit then those tend to do very well. But then you're left with an audience that only followed for more memes and dont really care about your original art. So it depends on what sort of account you have and what you want to post.

Growing out from a viral tweet like a meme feels good the first days but then you realize most of those followers are just void content. They wont interact with you, comment or like.

On the other hand, I really really hate the view count. My latest drawing has 2000 views and 50 likes. I cant help comparing to everyone else and "curiously" all my feed have amazing numbers/ratio. It makes you want to stop drawing.

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

>>6502375
Don't be too hard on yourself, art is subjective and everyone has different strengths and weaknesses. You can improve by studying the basics of composition, proportion, value, and perspective, and practicing regularly. Here are a few resources that may help:

1. Books: "Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain" by Betty Edwards and "Anatomy for the Artist" by Sarah Simblet are great starting points.
2. Online tutorials: Sites like YouTube and Skillshare offer a wide range of art tutorials, including how-to videos and online classes.
3. Practice: Draw every day, even if it's just for a few minutes. Start with simple still life setups and work your way up to more complex subjects.
4. Find inspiration: Look to other artists for inspiration and take note of what you admire about their work.

Remember, improvement takes time and practice. Keep a positive attitude and stay focused on your goals, and you'll be surprised at what you can accomplish.

posts.com:
>suggest he start studying proportions, forms, and art theory like perspective
He obviously needs to develop an understanding of the fundamental concept of drawing as a means to copy what he sees before he worries about other techniques.

Draw random lines on a piece of paper. On another piece, try to make exact duplications of these lines, trying to match the angle and lengths of the lines. You can check by aligning the edge of a pencil against your initial line, then keeping the pencil at the same angle, bringing your pencil over to your copy to check if the angle matches (you can check the length by aligning the tip of the pencil with one end of the line and your thumb with the other, and then bringing your pencil & thumb over to your copy). This is similar to visual measuring that you can do when drawing from life/photos (see https://youtu.be/bQrqGsT1LUE , but worry more about that after you've attempted some of the exercises below)

Do this:
https://enhancedrawing.com/what-is-drawing-upside-down/
Next step would be doing the same thing with upside down photographs, drawing lines to 1:1 represent the contours (see https://youtu.be/6n5TaEitmKE - if you were to make direct copies of the exact outer and inner contours lines she draws over the photographs in the video, youd have a good start to a drawing of the subject) of what you see in the photos (you can do this upside down as well).
Once you can do this halfway decently, try it with a right-side up photo. Before this exercise would be a good time to refer to the CTRLPaint video linked above. Also, consider using a grid (https://www.art-is-fun.com/grid-method)

Then you can try to draw what you see in real life, imagining that your vision is a flat plane, like a photo, concentrating on copying the contours of the objects, just as you did when copying the photos. Refer once again to the CTRLPaint video (in fact, just look through all his Unplugged videos https://www.ctrlpaint.com/videos/tag/Ctrl-Paint+Unplugged)

>>6502623
His Unplugged videos on negative space is another that will be particularly helpful in helping you bridge that gap between seeing and drawing.
Eventually you want these observational techniques to become second nature, integrated into a sketching process that will produce reasonably accurate drawings from observation, which you can then check and correct with visual measuring.
You'll also want to learn how to observe and then add values (light/dark -- shading) to your work, but for right now I'd worry more about the previous exercises and how they teach you to copy an exact image using lines.
Don't expect perfection, as your observational skills will always have room to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

I'm assuming these are all from same person yeah?
I'd suggest more decisive lines, try to visualize what you want to put down before you do. Looks like you're familiar with drawthrough method obviously, but yeah there is some inconsistencies in the perspective, but the drawings major issue is the hairy lines, also once you have that down don't get lost in the details, make sure it still reads as the object intended from a distance. You could also try drawing some mechanical objects in a 3 point perspective and see how you do. Hope that helps although You've probably heard similar advice before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6470632
the eyebrows arent in sync with the eyes hence the delayed action feeling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6491351
The first several frames should look like a ball (yours appears out of nowhere at speed)
Try having fewer frames and less squash when it impacts the ground
It should not slow out from the bounce, so try removing a few frames after the impact
You have blank frames, which is causing blinking; clean it up
As the ball approaches its apex, it should slow down because of gravity, so add more frames. At the top of its bounce it should become its roundest

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't fuss about it like some people do. drawing people, figures, anime 3d models and such is a better way of learning the form of something than by studying anatomy. That's important because, when stuff looks off, they usually say "go study anatomy", and so you waste a few hours looking at some bicep anatomy or whatever without actually getting any better forms. What you should really do is draw figures and 3d models and stuff, and like y'know, do some actual drawings. Anatomy doesn't teach form very well, it's more just to help when you're confused / having trouble with some particular part and want to know it better, so you take a peek inside or want a higher level of detail (which if you like cute things, you don't want). It isn't the main meat and potatoes, but a dish on the side; you genuinely shouldn't using it 90% of the time.

The reason why it's bad for form is kind of obvious when you think about it, your brain is not a 3D modeling program that can by know what something looks like from assembling internal ingredients. You're better off just looking at what it looks like, and putting it in ur visual library by drawing it. This is how artists naturally draw - from the visual library. they know what it's supposed to look like, and then try make it look like that, except pretty and good.

It's not good to be confused or lack understanding, but it is good to wing it as an artist, for most things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6503833
you just need to know how the muscles are placed and how they flow and interconnect with each other. Understanding how the bones affect the appearance on the outside is helpful too, say in areas like where the humerus connects with the tricep and creates that distinct shape and form. Metacarpals in the hand, cheek bones and planes of the face and the way they look from the outside under the flesh. It's good to have some general idea of what's going on under the skin to know what you're looking at on the outside.

The most important thing I'd say, is to make sure to look at photos of the outside of the body while you're studying bones and muscles, because sometimes it's difficult to connect what you're looking at under the skin to how it should look from the outside.

I'm at a bit of a breaking point here. I pove drawing and I've finally gotten to a point where I just draw what I like and have fun. It's taken me 7 or 8 years on and off drawing to finally just enjoy the process. I'm 24 years old and I'm by no means ashamed of how far I've come as an artist. In 7 years it cpuld be argued I should be damn near pro level by now, but half of this passion is just dealing with the internal struggle until you learn to love yourself.
My issue now is that I want to create art FOR something. Like a comic or a book or a TTRPG or a game. But every time I start a project I seem to get bored and burn out on it in a few months. This only happens with art related stuff. Anything else I can keep going forever. Hell, I'll still draw, but I won't work on my project after a while. Nothing I work on seems to "click" for me.
I guess I'm just asking if anyone else feels this way. Like you love to draw but you dont do anything with it.

posts.com:
>>6499286
Just like it took you 7 to 8 years to learn a good attitude to create art while enjoying the process. You have to learn to enjoy the process of making comics,games,ect. These things are diffucult tasks which take effort to create. I believe you are on the right track. Keep trying and thinking on how to achieve your goals in a healthy way. Plus remember you need to get to a high enough skill level where your creations naturally comeout. If its frustrating you, re-evaluate the goal and lower it to a skill level thats appropriate. So with comic making, if you get stuck on a full story, do a short story, and if you get stuck on a short story, do a one page scene. Keep lowering the bar till you can do that goal, and complete it, even on a bad day. Then build up from there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6499286
It's important to acknowledge the progress you've made and celebrate your growth as an artist. It's also common for people to lose motivation on projects, especially when they're related to their passions. To overcome this, it may help to identify what specific elements of a project are causing boredom or burnout, and finding ways to make those parts more interesting or manageable. Additionally, setting realistic goals and breaking projects down into smaller, manageable steps can help keep motivation levels high. It's also okay to take breaks and focus on other aspects of your life if you're feeling overwhelmed. Overall, it's a process of trial and error, so don't be too hard on yourself and keep experimenting until you find what works for you.

I keep going like that and finally I finished my first art. It's not good but throughout the struggles I learn a lot and the passion I had in the beginning returned.

I started another drawing and again learn more about what direction should I go. Sometimes I get stuck in detailing and I try to find a way to imply details instead of drawing everything. Sometimes there's part of the drawing looks good but It happen by accident so I try to emulate that. With every drawing I kept a note. And refer to it every time I start a new one.

Would like some feedback from experienced artists.
