>>6503284
It could just be a fun exercise though 5 mins is pushing it pretty hard and loses out on any intelligent decisions.

It’s kinda like whiteboard questions in programming interviews, it’s less about being right and more about proving you know what you’re talking about and can generally do what you’re claiming you can do. People don’t expect it to compile but if you claim to know Java and can’t use basic Java methods, it’s a red flag.
If you’re a concept artist but you can’t even do a basic gesture with a theme in 5 mins, there might be an issue.

But that would require the interviewer to be able to pick out the important bits and focus on them.

>i asked her to sketch a front and profile view of a teacher in 5 minutes.
kek. you must be a programmer to think that way about how long it would take to make something worthwhile from scratch, on the spot, with new specs, and nothing going wrong and no misunderstandings. that's the amount of time it might take to mechanically make the sketch, but not enough if you include reading and understanding the brief, and thinking about a concept. I've worked with too many software devs who estimate how long things will take in that same way.

given enough time, the idea of asking for a sketch like whiteboarding a small coding problem isn't inherently bad, though. when comics were more popular in the 50's, I think it was a common component of an interview -- but in that context, it was for entry level artists who were hired to knock out derivative shit quickly without screwing around. I don't think you will find someone at the level you're interviewing at who can pass that test very well, unless you get very lucky. that's almost kim jung gi-tier shit unless your in-house style is all balls and hoses.

that drawing does suck, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i just did this and wanted to add something that occurred to me that hadn’t been said yet:
if you’re hiring someone through hourly wages, it might actually be a bit of a bad thing for the interviewees if they explode their brains in dashing out their 110% best in that five minutes, and you get a really good result, because this opens up whole frontiers of potential uneasiness for the artists in working with you since they know you already do things irregularly (interview content:) it might seem like you could dually be irregular in the output demands you make of them, and in the payment (without weird questions,)
because employers with irregular processes feel like they could be unreliable, so it might feel to them that you might say way down the line when they’d already invested a lot in you:
‘why are you charging me for this great amount of time for ok things when you showed me you did that great design back in the interview in five minutes? you’re slacking and lying about the time it took, I’m disappointed in you (or, i’m not going to pay all that, there’s no way it could’ve taken you hours.)
creative energy is exhausting, and the adrenaline rush and superman focus in that five minutes could never be maintained consistently through the whole work day, so even if they did their best, it might feel like they’re shooting themselves in the foot, because they’re unsure of you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496876
The jump from trad to digital has its challenges if you go to screenless. But going screen tablet the hurdle is much less. You can get some cheap XP-Pen 16, 13 or 12 screen tablets. I bought the Innovator 16 in 2020 and now they came up with the 2nd Gen 16" tablet which is about half the price of my Innovator 16. (The only downside is the lack of dials). The other hurdles are picking the right color and right shading (if you're worried about messing up your coloring, just eyedrop until you the hang of it).

What you definitely should do is explore your drawing app for shortcuts, key modifiers and templates/auto actions as it could half the amount of time you'd spend working. Eg: I bind the alt button to common tool eraser so I dont need to switch tools to erase at all. It cuts down 1-2 seconds, but it adds up. Ctrl+Shift is for layer select, so I could immediately jump to which layer I want to work on by tapping on the screen instead of layer hunting in the layer window/tool panel.

>>6496876
Consider this: as a /beg/, you're going to need tons of mileage. Hundreds of hours of drawing. With trad, if you carry a sketchpad and pen around with you, you can squeeze in as much sketching as possible. While eating breakfast, in line at the bank, drunk driving down the wrong side of the highway, the possibilities are endless. If you go digital only, you're going to have a set time out of your day where you need to be at your computer doing nothing but drawing. Can you resist the urge to open up a web browser, fap, play vidya, etc.? Do you have a block of your time you can be at your PC? Just something to consider. Otherwise, no, it doesn't really matter, I'm sure there are plenty of successful cartoonists who are primarily digital only.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496876
Starting with digital art as a beginner is not necessarily wrong, but it's important to understand that the skills developed in digital art are not exactly the same as those developed in traditional art. The skills you hone in digital art are centered around the use of software and technology, while traditional art focuses more on fundamental techniques.

However, starting with digital art can be tempting, especially if you're interested in doing cartoon or stylized work, as you can quickly achieve results with the tools available in digital art software.

A potential pitfall of starting digitally is that it can be tempting to rely too heavily on the tools and shortcuts provided by the software, rather than developing your fundamental drawing skills. This can result in a lack of control over the creation process and a lack of understanding of traditional techniques and mediums.

If you do decide to start with digital art, my advice would be to start by learning the traditional techniques and principles of drawing, such as anatomy, perspective, and lighting. This will give you a solid foundation to build upon as you learn the digital tools.

Additionally, consider trying out traditional mediums, such as pencils and charcoal, to help you understand and develop the core skills involved in creating art. This will also give you a more well-rounded skillset and make it easier for you to transition to traditional art down the road, if you so choose.

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6493866
confidence is key when making art. if you're hesitant with your forms you'll end up with hard to read pictures. when you choose a focal point in the picture, really focus on making the forms there clear, don't be afraid to use ambient occlusion to emphasise the form. also work on your flow, even if your study doesn't have a clear flow of focus, make it up in your digital painting.

>>6493762
to call hesitancy impressionism is kind of a miss, impressionist masters were very intentional and confident in their painting. you can do it digitally too if your process and post-process is done well

as a paintover this might be useless as it changes too much of the original mood, but maybe this can help give you some ideas for how to design your lighting in order to create areas of interest in future paintings.

group your values, emphasize your focal point, and remember to include common light effects you'd see in nature like reflected lights, atmospheric perspective, ambient light affecting the colors in shadow.

Lacks line confidence. You have generally got things going in the right direction but you need to not make composite ("hairy") lines.
>>6489478
>>6489618
For coloring, you need to learn your tools a bit better. That as a completed image should only take you 3-4 hours of work at the absolute most. Things like using masks, auto-color tools, how to paint bucket effectively, and so on immensely helps with that kind of cel shading you're doing.
Try disabling Ctrl+Z for a month.


Basically your problem is that you are taking too long to complete each stage of a drawing. Accept your imperfections with the knowledge that producing art faster makes you better.
Making 5, increasingly-detailed sketches overlaid on top of each other using confident strokes takes less time than the 2-3 you did there using unconfident strokes.

Additionally your commission sheet needs to have its basics easily grasped from a twitter/deviantart/etc thumbnail. Offered levels of polish and prices primarily. Never use "percentages" to change pricing, and discounts look better than additional fees.

>>6502758
You don’t need to master anatomy or any other skill to do well in it. Stylizing is far more important for success. It needs to look good for people to want to spend money on it. Think about finishing some of your sketches. It’s more important to be able to create a finished, colored piece that can stand on its own. Clients don’t want sketches or perfect anatomy, they want pretty pictures. Just have solid fundies and start stylizing. Don’t get stuck striving for mastery, it’s a beg-trap.

>>6500870
No idea if this is just another AI bait thread or not, but I will be very honest to you: Don't bet solely on it. Have a plan B. I have witnessed first-hand when the Internet came along. I remember when Tim-Berners Lee was sitting in his chair on the '94 conference explaining what he just invented (the WWW as we know it). People were ignorant and incredibly dismissive of what WWW would bring to us. I have seen people, companies, etc. fail terribly due to their ignorance and inaccurate prediction. Please don't make the same mistakes.

What I'm trying to say, anon, is that you should do the best that you can, but to have an alternative plan at hand. AI will absolutely be the next big thing in this and the following decade. It will probably happen even faster than with the Internet. It will make the requirements for jobs much harder to met, jobs will be replaced, etc. Yes, I'm aware of the political, social and philosophical consequences and I can also understand the nihilist depression that recent trends of AI has caused. But the best you can do right now is to look forward. Do what you can do best, but prepare for the worst.

posts.com:
While not anime uniquely, I think the focus on stylization is an important trend.

Historically it was all about capturing reality as realistically as possible, but with cameras and other modern techniques its extremely easy to do that.
For awhile that forced artists to delve into the abstract and other nonsensical forms of expression, but lets be honest, its just a laughable subversion that only got popular because everything thought they were being clever by calling a toilet art.

The focus on stylization such as that seen in anime allows for expression of purpose and ideas. Instead of limiting yourself to drawing things as realistic as possible, you focus primarily on the ideas and concepts you want to show off, and because you don't need to be tied down to the static nature of realistic figures or the inflexible proportions they have, it lets people be more creative with what they're expressing.

Something like pic rel would be completely impossible to replicate by the old masters because real women are ugly and have right feet.

>>6494920
I agree, but less pessimistic about AI being the end of drawing and art. I do think AI will accelerate style trends, generic brands of anime and digital art ('artstation' style) will oversaturate and burn out.
I think we'll return to highly individualistic artist styles. If you look at early American comic strips there was a diversity of styles, from surrealist funny animals to realistic cinematic strips.
The influence of anime/manga is huge. Its effects will be more subtle though (for instance, though I draw in an American style, I'm inspired by the pacing of manga). I think we'll see more international style(s), with artists absorbing all these global influences to develop their quirky styles, with also a return to traditional media to differentiate from the AI behemoth.
Of course, no one has a crystal ball, but history shows that with art every action has a reaction. Artists tend to be very resilient to adapting to changing technology and society, but often in unexpected ways.

>>6490877
It's true that anime has gained popularity and has its own unique style, but to say that it's the "new Renaissance" is an overstatement. The Renaissance was a cultural, historical, and artistic movement that greatly impacted the Western world and set the foundation for modern art. It was a time of great innovation and experimentation in the arts, which had a profound influence on the cultural, political, and social aspects of society.

Anime, on the other hand, is primarily meant to be lighthearted entertainment. It is enjoyed by many for its unique storytelling, colorful characters, and imaginative worlds. While it can contain elements of art, it is not meant to be taken as a serious artistic movement.

Like chick that imprints on its mother, maybe there is some primal part that is born and dies throught the day and when I sit to draw, I'm making that primal subconscious part of me say "Hey, I draw, I will draw now."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6502678
One thought I tend to consider when drawing a character in an environment is to try and make them not engage with the audience. Have them interact with their surroundings, or be occupied with their own business, so they're part of a whole, rather than the focus. While technically this may not yield immediate results, it may help change your mindset about your characters, and thus help better integrate them in to their context.

AI artists today need to
>Understand the various models on the market
There's like 10 viable latest models, each with different styles and quirks
>Understand the innumerable number of parameters
CFG scale, VAEs (for coloring), CLIP skip, prompting, upscale algorithms.
>In many cases, know how to fine-tune models.
It used to be textual inversion, then dreambooth, now the hotness is LORA, to consistently reproduce characters.

>Make your own 3d models for posing, or even 3d videos to serve as feed for conversion
852 made his own 3d base videos for conversion.

When it started out, it was just the 'proompters', and people thought it'll be easy, cause you can just copy-paste the prompts. Now its gotten more complex, not less, as AI has developed.

AI artist is absolutely going to be a job title in a year or two. It'll be a natural progression from technical artists. Basic python + 3d art + model knowledge + art basics, and these jobs are going to pay well.

Yeah, just like how web dev got 'automated', right?
Webpages started out as text-HTML pages, and indeed with better technology, the HTML generation could be automated.
Guess what, people made more advanced webpages, using those technology, that couldn't be automated.

People + AI beats AI alone, so the AI artist will always have a large advantage over what a pure AI can do without an experienced person.

Plus, an AI artist is already going to be 5x-10x more efficient than a manual artist. There's little profit to be made from automating the last parts, because you aren't saving much in labour costs by that point. Like an airplane is always going to have a pilot, even if 95% of the flight is automated. Game and animation studios will absolutely still want AI artists to supervise/fine tune the models for actual production use.

>>6505118
> to the clients that matter
Escaping upmarket sounds attractive, but exactly how you get killed by disruptive innovation.
Go read the book on disruptive innovation, many companies have faced exactly this problem
>New technology comes out, that is radically cheaper, but the quality is no good for the current well-paying customers
>Hence existing companies don't invest all-in the technology, because the new tech has no paying customers
>Turns out with a massively lower cost, a new market of cheap customers appears out of nowhere (Turns out plenty of people are willing to pay for AI commissions when they get 10 quality pics for $50)
>The new technology now has a paying market, so can reinvest in itself, to iterate and improve, way faster than the old technology.
>The new technology gets so good, with a massive mature ecosystem, that even the top paying clients switch over to the new tech.

>>6501777

No you don't. You can get way too wrapped up in the skeleton and muscle groups and the stuff that you won't actually see in a finished drawing. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Learn a basic proportionate skeleton, no you don't need to make 1 to 1 perfect renders. learn the origins and insertions of the muscles. Try to identify the muscles on images or ideally in person and observe how they stretch,compress, twist and pull. Learning the names is not necessary, but can help as a lot; Some, if not all, have their locations and functions baked in. For example, a peroneus usually has a brevis, supra means above infra mean below, medial is typically to the core lateral on the outer side, etc.

>Why learn the skeleton if you never see it?
Its a structure thing, like a building, stronger foundations yield better results.
>Isn't it a waste of time to learn things like the skeleton and muscles when you will never see them?
Not necessarily, you would be training your basic drawing skills all the while training your knowledge; Its actually very efficient. Just like your skeletons are your foundation for your muscles, your knowledge of anatomy and form you will develop is the foundation for drapery, armor, etc.
>But I don't want to draw X all day.
No one should be telling you to forever study. Your studies are like weight training, its something you will do for the rest of your life should you stick with drawing, there is no 'graduating' from fundamentals. Study and apply to the things you're actually interested in, but if you neglect your training your goals will suffer. Study, apply, assess and correct with either more studies or intent.
>I want to draw X do I really need to lean anatomy?
You have everything to gain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6502348
You don’t need to learn about the minute details and shapes of the skeleton in order to draw very simple basic stick figure tier skeletons as foundations. Getting the proportions are fine. Don’t need to learn all about the complex shapes of the notches and processes or how they connect to fucking tendons/cartilage. If people aren’t going to be drawing for anatomy books or drawing gore with exposed bones and inner flesh, keeping it simple is all they need.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Studying final images is like memorizing the answer to a math problem. Studying simplified construction forms is like memorizing formulas. Studying anatomy is understanding the reasoning behind the formulas. The better and more completely you understand, the more intuitive it becomes, and the more easily you can manipulate and apply what you know.

Not op but I have a related question.

For the people who did Morpho exercises, did it really help you with your anatomy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6501739
literally copy anatomical diagrams. develop a masochistic taste for it. learn the fucking names of the muscles and bones, and quiz yourself on them. like with flash cards.

do figure studies and note the anatomy while you're working. do anatomical drawovers of photos, too, if you want. you have to reinforce your knowledge against the real thing.

make yourself draw anatomy from memory, without reference, in as much detail as possible. then compare your work to photos and diagrams to learn your weaknesses and systematically eliminate them.

construction techniques are useful. learn some good ones. I like bridgman's. copy bridgman pages ad nauseam.

this stuff is all like doing pushups. you're burning it into your brain through miserable study, repetition and testing your recall. it's relatively mindless, though, so it's easy. just tedious.

this anon gets it >>6502408

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6501007
The shadow isn't as hard cut as you're making it out to be. The shadows will be more diffuse if the casting object is future away. The hand is dar so the edges would be softer unless it's a spotlight shining on him. But you don't need to be 100% accurate on where you're placing the shadows, look at some pictures of cell shaded figures and get an idea of how they draw shadows and where.

those are gesture practices

>what did you do to get this far in construction

draw spheres, boxes, cylinderes, carve, crack and break them and attach them to each other, draw rice bags stretching, twisting and being squished. once you get somewhat good at that, choose a basic figure drawing book and copy it entirely (hampton and morpho is what I used). draw those dolls on top of pictures and also draw them by eye measuring. try to have fun while doing all that by using your creativity and don't sob when it doesnt look amazing, just keep doing it and it will improve

Fundies inform your studies inform your finished pieces. The "optimal balance" is going to depend on the individual. Spend about half the time drawing whatever the hell you want. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Keys to Drawin. "Standing Figure". This is my worst work yet. I decided to try to rush it, because I usually take ~5+ hours to finish one exercise and I actually don't have that much time to draw, because I'm a full time salaryman. So this took about 2 hours top. It's really jarring to look at my work and reference side by side. I guess, the moral of the story is to not rush it.
But hey, the actual point of the exercise was to find the mid point and draw the figure filling the entire page, not too small, not too big and with accurate proportions, so I guess I somewhat succeeded. Well, I made her ass too big and her left side too low and her legs look really long, but it's not too bad for a turbobeg, right?
I'll just leave it as it is and try harder next exercise.

posts.com: I think I’m starting to go mad. Whenever I look at a reference or an object in real life, I can easily see the negative space, outline of the object, and the spatial relationship between each part of the object and its surroundings, but when it comes time to draw it, my lines almost always fail to accurately capture what I see. For example, if I try to draw my hand, I can see the shape and every line/detail but when I put my pencil to paper, I immediately make a line that’s about 60% accurate to what I’m seeing, then the drawing ends up being about 40% accurate because I’m making the wrong kind of curve, line, sttoke compared to what I’m seeing, and I don’t know how to fix this. posts.com:
>>6503367
>don't really know how i'm supposed to do details
being lazy with details is kind of a blessing imo. with painting, it's easy to get distracted by details before getting the big things right, e.g. proportion, value, etc. you seem to have a good start with getting the big things right. your studies look like good starter block-ins.

getting details right is hard, but if you're going for a painterly style (as opposed to atomic-level accuracy) I think you just have to pick out important details with hard edges and emphasize contrast until you think it sells. for example, the thin purple lines in the onion wedge where the skin forms layers, and the striations and variable translucency of the inner flesh.

>>6504295
thats only 12 circles, it wont do a dime. If you are interested this is what I'm doing, I'm seeing great results in my line quality both in fast and slow traces, on digital and trad.

Motor skills comes down to accuracy and speed, from research it shows that the acquisition of motor skill is almost independent of age the only thing that changes movement top speed on the movement, so you will never be too old to improve, but it takes daily sessions for 10 weeks to cement the pattern in your muscle memory (this is from some boxing studies).

So... I use this template to trace the first time use a stop watch to time how much it takes to trace 5 times each figure, then use that time race against in coming sessions. Every movement comes from the should, elbow and wrist never fingers. Use the same zoom % through out the session I use 37.3% zoom and brush at 4px without pressure sensitivity.

I started timing 22 min now after 10 days I'm at 10 min while retaining the same accuracy or better than the first time. You will feel a flare in under your scapula due to weak and dumb muscles, after a few sessions you will feel nothing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6504838
>i hate to be that guy but... wouldnt it be easier to use cylinders and spheres instead of boxes?
nta, not really if you use cylinders you will be losing 1 dimension of information (cylinder = height, radius and angle; you are replacing one of the dimensions for an angle roughly speaking) this one of the reasons many drawn faces feel flat they are thinking as a cylinder which makes 3d harder , on the other side with a box you have a well define x,y,z space you can carve into the box more easily.

tl;dr the brain process information more easily with boxes (cartesian system) than cylinders (polar system)

posts.sub: You wanna know what makes for true art?
posts.com:
True art appeals to everyone in every class of life.

Anything else is the loud hypnosis of a niche sub-(i hate to use the word culture here, because that gives to much credit to them, think culture in the sense of a bacterial culture) culture.

Their insecurity, fraught with obviousness, embarassing, anti-mimetic qualities come off as literally: bottled anger serving no purpose.

a squirm, a belch, a sneeze is their entire existence. To shock and absorb all qualities of life considered positive, one must have an inherently negative agenda, and also be blissfully ignorant and self-righteous enough to not only be unaware of said agenda, but to also caustically remind the remaining 6 people you haven't alienated: I AM GOD HEAR ME ROAR.

We understand, we get it. I understand it like so, (you) the viewer, our audience, have no idea of the capabilities of intelligence, and we can't predict pure instability.
The point I'm trying to make is, thanks to the internet™'s influence, the world is positively controlled by outliers. The barbaric, and savage, you wish.

This reverse culture plot hole will be torn at the seams and (ta-da~! )

What I'm saying is nothing.
HE'S SAYING NOTHING?

Yes. It is possible to live a life so pure of heart and reason, all the whilst reaping the benefits of our culture, it just takes time money and effort.
The cancerous guck is everywhere, so how do we extract gold from it?

posts.com:
>>6503259
First of all, that is body fat, it looks the way it does in most of your pictures for two reasons:
1. the abs group is relaxed and it becomes 'squished' together in picture 1, 5 and 6 (reads left to right, from the upper side to the lower side).
2. females develop fat in that particular area (lower ab group, not reaching the pubic area), and in that particular fashion (the fat suddenly cuts under the dermis, that's why artists depict it that way). This is not to say males can't develop fat in that area, they can, but not to the point of females generally, and surely not ideally when being depicted.
Now, where can you study it? swim over to /s/, look out for images focusing on the frontal torso and see how light draws the volume on the figure of women. That will give you a basic idea of what the fuck is going on.
Then, pick up a construction book (morpho or Hampton are of my liking), go to the torso section and look how they differentiate the male and female ab group. Hampton draws the male one like a rectangle but like a violin with its wider side on the lower half, this is because most of the models have enough fat in their lower abs (see what I'm talking about?) so artists can use that approach to simplify that area.
And after that, you can head over to Stonehouse's anatomy and look out for the fat section, he actually draws fats and the sections where it gets stored most of the time in the human figure.
And to finalize, you can torrent one of those anatomy atlases for med students and look for the fat tissue sections.

As a side note, what you are circling is not a single thing or fat tissue, what you are circling is the lower half of the whole fat tied to the abs, it just looks like one thing because of the two halves overlapping.

>>6499177
graphic novel publishing from the big indies (other than image which is just DC Marvel with shiny paint) the US/CA market is usually a one off gig, you're not under contract for multiple volumes and usually can't even get a series released. you're usually sending in a basically finished manuscript and they're fine with edgy. some of the classic US indie comics are chock full of jokes abut the MCs being pedos and whatever (megahex for example) so you don't end up as a slave, but it has its own issues.

it seems hard to get much traction with webcomics these days, but i would definitely keep working on that. well-designed website with more than 30 pages on it at launch, get people to link it.
if you're not completely cash-starved making print copies of the first 2 chapters and selling doujins at an anime con (especially one of the bigger ones like AnEx) could be worth your time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AI art's real cool ability would be to streamline animation processes.

Imagine instead of drawing 2400 pictures, you just did spot work on same pictures, and every time you did the work got more to what you would draw. Like you just put in character sheets, (mapped to every angle, like the 3d presentation of 2d art) built standard packs to understand drawn rules about hair or accessories to a basic extent, and over time with improvement it figured out what you wanted. All that time spent on inbetweens spent on just making the finished product.

That sounds cool, that sounds like a benefit to animation. Programs that can help to speed up the craft, leave people more time to make more material, that's the net benefit. It'd be like getting mad we don't use printing presses with specific blocks anymore for printing that you have to take out by hand and swap and shit, typing a prompt into a computer is still an action of an individual, it's still the performance of crafting, it's still art you made with your actions.

>>6498026
Practicing regularly is actually the key. If you want to push a bit further, add some days where you draw a lot, like once or twice a week.
But yeah, drawing one hour everyday will take you far because :
- it becomes an habit
- in terms of raw hours of practice you'll probably still beat someone who draw a lot once in a while at the end of the month, let alone at the end of the year.
- sleep is an important factor in learning and acquiring new things, your brain processes what you did during the day, so by practicing one hour everyday, you'll learn things every nights too, double practice in a sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I first started as a beg I forced myself to draw 2 hours a day every day to forge the habit for about a month (1 hour would probably work too).
Then I felt the form for the first time and all of a sudden I actually wanted to draw because it was fun. Hours I spent drawing naturally began to increase.
So yeah, building the habit to start with is the most important thing. Give yourself the time to find out if you actually enjoy this hobby. Check in with yourself every couple of months to see if you’re happy bumping your hours up a bit, but no matter what keep that hour as a baseline. Unless you’re 100% sure you hate drawing. Then quit.

posts.com: I want to start learning the Reilly method, should I start with Mark Westermoe, the Watts Atelier program, or watch the youtube tutorials of Bradwynn Jones and Salem Shanouha? Did I miss any other important source on the subject?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6505618
I've watched all (charcoal/graphite) Watts Atelier videos, studied from them and it certainly made me a better traditional artist. It's pretty big though so you'll have to take your time to digest it all, especially since all teachers have their own quirks and way of going about it, some you'll like better than others.

From a quick Googling:
Mark Westermoe seems solid and legit.
Bradwynn Jones seems pretty alright. Looks like a high-tier student, is the feel I'm getting.
Salem Shanouha seems to be the weakest skill/appeal-wise.

So in short you can't go wrong with any of the top 3. Imo you'd be fine trying Brad first since he seems to break things down well, so it'd give you a good introduction to the method. Then once you've got a decent grip on it, I'd recommend diving through the Watts Atelier, especially to see how Watts execute things himself, since he's not as systematic and you could say there's more nuances to get from him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6505618
Also I'd like to point out that you don't have to be so rigid about the material you're using. You don't have to get Conté of Wolff pencils, nor you have to get big sheets to work on. You can do everything with graphite pencils on A4 print paper (so long as it's smooth) if you'd like, it won't cause any issues (I've tried all different ways).
Of course Watts will tell you to buy all these stuff so you get to have the same materials they have over there at the Atelier, but the truth is even he himself later down the road tells you that it doesn't matter and you can use whatever you want to use.
What matters is understanding the concepts and fundamentals you're taught, and all of these can be done by sharpening and using a graphite pencil the same way you'd do so with a bigger charcoal/carbon pencil. Or digital even.

>>6488300
This answer applies to any artist that's teaching something: Is their teaching method clicking with you and getting you excited to draw and learn? If so, then go for it.

Life is too short to worry about whether you're learning "the right thing" or not. If the artist has a style and approach that's appealing to you and you want similar end results then great! Not many artists share their process so candidly, and if there's tons of resources and they teach in a way that clicks with you then don't take those for granted and just start drawing. If you change your mind and want to switch tracks then you'll still have learned something anyway.

>>6500181
step 3 and 2 are best done in tandem with each other, gesture works well as a warmup,

>>6500211
bargue plates, the most valuable thing you can learn in proportion, proportion is what nearly EVERY drawing fucks up completely, perspective may be fucked, but when people cant draw something in perspective they avoid doing so, but proportion is fundamentally the most important concept you need to do, I mean, when you draw a stick figure, you have a head, then the proportion from the head to the waste where the legs start, then with how long you make the arms, you can, within 10 seconds, analyze the pose you want to draw and see if its fundamentally fucked up or not, but if you suck at proportion, you may find out hour 2 that the arm is about 1 foot longer than it should be, the hand is half the size it should be, and what the fuck is going on with that leg.

bargue plates, has fantastic reference material in the book, which is online for free, doing that along with drawing from life, just shit on your desk, shit in your house, whatever, will also instill some level of perspective.

from here, learn how to place basic 3d objects in space from scratch, this is just perspective and an application of proportion.

and from here, I would probably look into watts "Bridgman’s Anatomy with Erik Gist" or youtubes deciphering bridgeman,

this should be able to take you to where you want to get to.

remember, proportion > perspective > anatomy/construction in that order.

along the way you will also learn value just by application of what you are doing,
